title: John Kerry to Visit Brussels on Friday
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004288661" crop="592" type="image"]

Secretary of State John Kerry will travel to Brussels on Friday to meet with Belgian and European officials, and to express his condolences to the people of Brussels.

https://twitter.com/statedeptspox/status/712686806983176192

“Attacks like these only deepen shared resolve to defeat terrorism around the world,” he  said. 

Mr. Kerry  is now in Moscow, and is scheduled to meet President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russian officials on Thursday to discuss the situations in Ukraine and Syria.
content_expanded:
Secretary of State John Kerry will travel to Brussels on Friday to meet with Belgian and European officials, and to express his condolences to the people of Brussels.

.@JohnKerry will travel to #Brussels on Friday to express condolences for loss of life in terrorist attacks & meet w/ Belgian, EU officials.

— John Kirby (@statedeptspox) March 23, 2016

“Attacks like these only deepen shared resolve to defeat terrorism around the world,” he said.

Mr. Kerry is now in Moscow, and is scheduled to meet President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russian officials on Thursday to discuss the situations in Ukraine and Syria.

title: Watch: ISIS’ Signature Explosive in Europe, Explained
content:
An explosive favored by the Islamic State in Europe, TATP, may have been used in the Brussels attacks.

title: Obama, in Buenos Aires, Pledges  to Pursue ISIS  ‘Aggressively’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004288617" crop="592" type="image"]


President Obama said on Wednesday that he would continue to “aggressively” go after the Islamic State in the wake of terrorist attacks in Belgium that he described as “senseless, vicious violence.”

“Today the people of the United States and Argentina stand with the Belgian people and express our extraordinary sorrow for the losses that they’ve experienced," Mr. Obama said after a meeting with his Argentine counterpart, Mauricio Macri. "We understand the pain they feel viscerally. The United States will continue to offer any assistance that we can to help investigate these attacks and bring these attackers to justice." The comments were Mr. Obama's first extended reaction to the attacks.

The attacks have disrupted and overshadowed Mr. Obama’s  trip this week, a familiar phenomenon for a president who has repeatedly seen his visits overseas to promote his foreign policy overtaken by a terrorism-related crisis elsewhere.

In this case, the Belgium bombings unfolded just as Mr. Obama was in Cuba to celebrate a historic diplomatic opening he regards as a pivotal piece of his legacy. He was in Argentina on Wednesday for meetings with Mr. Macri, the country’s new president,  meant to showcase a new era of cooperation after decades of strain.

Mr. Macri began his remarks by expressing condolences to Belgium and solidarity. He told Mr. Obama their meeting was a chance for him to “share with you this grief all of us around the world have felt in the face of this new cruel and devastating attack.”

“Once again, it’s a good opportunity to reflect with you on the fact that fanaticism brings intolerance, aggression and violence, which leads to nowhere,” Mr. Macri said.
content_expanded:
President Obama said on Wednesday that he would continue to “aggressively” go after the Islamic State in the wake of terrorist attacks in Belgium that he described as “senseless, vicious violence.”

“Today the people of the United States and Argentina stand with the Belgian people and express our extraordinary sorrow for the losses that they’ve experienced,” Mr. Obama said after a meeting with his Argentine counterpart, Mauricio Macri. “We understand the pain they feel viscerally. The United States will continue to offer any assistance that we can to help investigate these attacks and bring these attackers to justice.” The comments were Mr. Obama’s first extended reaction to the attacks.

The attacks have disrupted and overshadowed Mr. Obama’s trip this week, a familiar phenomenon for a president who has repeatedly seen his visits overseas to promote his foreign policy overtaken by a terrorism-related crisis elsewhere.

In this case, the Belgium bombings unfolded just as Mr. Obama was in Cuba to celebrate a historic diplomatic opening he regards as a pivotal piece of his legacy. He was in Argentina on Wednesday for meetings with Mr. Macri, the country’s new president, meant to showcase a new era of cooperation after decades of strain.

Mr. Macri began his remarks by expressing condolences to Belgium and solidarity. He told Mr. Obama their meeting was a chance for him to “share with you this grief all of us around the world have felt in the face of this new cruel and devastating attack.”

“Once again, it’s a good opportunity to reflect with you on the fact that fanaticism brings intolerance, aggression and violence, which leads to nowhere,” Mr. Macri said.

title: Belgian King and Queen Visit Hospitals
content: [nytmedia id="100000004288582" crop="592" type="image"] Belgium's king and queen on Wednesday visited the Brussels Airport, where they paid tribute to the attack victims, and two hospitals where survivors were being treated for injuries. The palace posted an image on Twitter of King Philippe and Queen Mathilde meeting with hospital staff at the military hospital Reine Astrid. https://twitter.com/MonarchieBe/status/712655814570471424 Earlier Wednesday, the royal couple observed a moment of silence alongside political leaders at the European Commission building. In a rare public address on Tuesday, King Philippe declared “our country is in mourning.” “The broken lives, the deep wounds — this suffering is that of our whole country,” he said.
content_expanded:
Belgium’s king and queen on Wednesday visited the Brussels Airport, where they paid tribute to the attack victims, and two hospitals where survivors were being treated for injuries.

The palace posted an image on Twitter of King Philippe and Queen Mathilde meeting with hospital staff at the military hospital Reine Astrid.

Briefing à L'Hôpital militaire de Neder-over-Heembeek qui accueille de nombreuses victimes des attentats pic.twitter.com/8VX8bNvA29

— Belgian Royal Palace (@MonarchieBe) March 23, 2016

Earlier Wednesday, the royal couple observed a moment of silence alongside political leaders at the European Commission building.

In a rare public address on Tuesday, King Philippe declared “our country is in mourning.”

“The broken lives, the deep wounds — this suffering is that of our whole country,” he said.

title: Chilling Reminder for a Belgian Muslim Playwright
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004288183" crop="480" type="image"]

Since last year, “Djihad,” the Belgian playwright Ismaël Saidi’s comic play about three hapless Belgian Muslims who travel to Syria, has been packing houses across Belgium and fueling discussion about homegrown Islamic radicalism and discontented youth.

But the terrorist attacks in Brussels, which included the suicide bombing of a central subway station, hit especially close to home for Mr. Saidi: His 16-year-old son had taken the subway that morning.

“I was watching the news, then I heard about the subway and I thought about my son,” Mr. Saidi said in a telephone interview on Wednesday. “I tried to reach him for 20 or 30 minutes.”

Finally, the two connected. “He had exited the subway just one stop before,” Mr. Saidi said. “So we’re very lucky.”

Mr. Saidi said he wasn’t surprised by the attacks, which killed at least 31 people and wounded 270 others. 

“We all were waiting for something like this to happen,” he said. 

“It’s the same feeling as looking through the window when a storm is coming,” he added. “It’s a mix of sadness and anger because you know that maybe we could have done something. You never know.”

Mr. Saidi, 39, a former Brussels policeman and a practicing Muslim, is one of the three actors in “Djihad.” 

They performed the play the night before the attacks. 

“That’s the weird part for us as artists,” he said. “We’re talking about three guys going to Syria to do jihad who then go back to Brussels and are involved in an attack.”

Plans were already in place for the tour to resume in April in Belgium and France. 

The play uses a light, humane approach to touch on Islamic radicalism, anti-Semitism, joblessness and hopelessness among young Muslim men in Belgium, which has a high per capita number of citizens leaving to fight in Syria. 

“Djihad” was broadcast on Belgian television just after the Paris attacks last November. Mr. Saidi said that more than 47,000 people had seen it live since it first opened in December 2014, including 25,000 high school students.

A Flemish version is now on tour with a different cast, and the play has also been translated into English.

“They adore it,” Mr. Saidi said of the students. 

After the play, he often holds discussions with the students, the actors and guest imams and journalists.

“We’re talking about terrorism, about a lot of stuff they cannot talk about in the classroom,” Mr. Saidi said. “When they see the news it’s not easy to talk about it with their parents.”

Belgian politicians have been eager to champion the play. But after receiving government support for the school performances, in January Mr. Saidi turned down the funding, fearing that his artistic independence was being caught up in Belgian politics. 

In his memoir, “Moi, Ismaël, un musulman d’ici” (“Me, Ismaël, a Muslim From Here”), Mr. Saidi talks about growing up in a rough area of Brussels. 

His father, who immigrated to Belgium from Morocco in the 1960s and worked as a taxi driver, urged him to attend a good high school in a better neighborhood.

That was where “I found out that white people exist,” he said. “All my friends, and even me, if we were saved, it was because of education.”

Mr. Saidi said he did not believe in “de-radicalization,” but in preventing people from becoming radical. 

“The first part is education inside the family," he said. "The way Muslims teach Islam to their kids has to change. And the second part is education in schools. We cannot afford to have those schools from the ghetto where no one learns anything but no one cares because it’s in the ghetto.”

“I don’t think you need to go outside your country and fight or die,” he added. “If you don’t find a reason to live, you find a reason to die.”
content_expanded:

title: Adele Dedicates Performance to Brussels
content:
Adele paid homage in a concert to the victims of the Brussels attacks, asking audience members on Tuesday night to sing along as she dedicated a performance of her song “Make You Feel My Love” to the city.

“This is for Brussels tonight,” the singer said to a packed audience at the O2 Arena in London. “I want you to all sing it with me.”

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rhw8rfrYgmA

Fans at the venue raised their lit cellphones above their heads as she sang. “Don’t think I’ve ever actually been so moved in my life,” she said when the song ended.

“I think they heard us,” she added.
content_expanded:
Adele paid homage in a concert to the victims of the Brussels attacks, asking audience members on Tuesday night to sing along as she dedicated a performance of her song “Make You Feel My Love” to the city.

“This is for Brussels tonight,” the singer said to a packed audience at the O2 Arena in London. “I want you to all sing it with me.”

Fans at the venue raised their lit cellphones above their heads as she sang. “Don’t think I’ve ever actually been so moved in my life,” she said when the song ended.

“I think they heard us,” she added.

title: Britain Offers to Help With Belgian Investigation
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004288212" crop="190" type="image"]

Britain sent police and intelligence officers to Belgium to assist with the investigation into the Paris terrorist attacks last year, and it has offered to send more help after the assaults in Brussels, the British government said on Wednesday.

Speaking in Parliament on Wednesday, Prime Minister David Cameron said that British officers were already “embedded” in Belgium as part of counterterrorism efforts, although he did not specify how many.

The home secretary, Theresa May, said that Britain had now offered additional support in areas “where we have an expertise which could be of benefit to the Belgians.”

Even before the attacks on Tuesday, Ms. May said, the British authorities had been discussing measures to tighten border controls at Belgian ports served by ferries from Britain.

She rejected claims from Donald J. Trump, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, that British Muslims were not helping to identify suspected terrorists.

“This is absolutely not the case," Ms. May told lawmakers. "He is just plain wrong.”

“We do see there are people in Muslim communities around the United Kingdom who are as concerned as everybody else is in the U.K., both about the attacks that have taken place, but also about the perversion of Islam, which underlies the ideology that has led to violence,” she said.
content_expanded:
Britain sent police and intelligence officers to Belgium to assist with the investigation into the Paris terrorist attacks last year, and it has offered to send more help after the assaults in Brussels, the British government said on Wednesday.

Speaking in Parliament on Wednesday, Prime Minister David Cameron said that British officers were already “embedded” in Belgium as part of counterterrorism efforts, although he did not specify how many.

The home secretary, Theresa May, said that Britain had now offered additional support in areas “where we have an expertise which could be of benefit to the Belgians.”

Even before the attacks on Tuesday, Ms. May said, the British authorities had been discussing measures to tighten border controls at Belgian ports served by ferries from Britain.

She rejected claims from Donald J. Trump, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, that British Muslims were not helping to identify suspected terrorists.

“This is absolutely not the case,” Ms. May told lawmakers. “He is just plain wrong.”

“We do see there are people in Muslim communities around the United Kingdom who are as concerned as everybody else is in the U.K., both about the attacks that have taken place, but also about the perversion of Islam, which underlies the ideology that has led to violence,” she said.

title: Refunds Available for Brussels-Bound Air Travelers
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004288251" crop="592" type="image"]

With Brussels Airport closed through at least Thursday, most airlines responded by putting into effect change and refund policies for passengers with tickets arriving at or departing from Belgium’s capital.

Regardless of airline policies, travel insurance may protect Brussels-bound travelers, said Stan Sandberg, a founder of the insurance comparison site TravelInsurance.com.

Many travel insurance plans offer trip cancellation coverage for terrorist attacks that are recognized as such by the State Department in Washington, provided the coverage is bought before the assault, he said. The typical cancellation coverage will apply to travelers who are scheduled to travel within seven to 30 days of the attack.

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/23/travel/with-brussels-airport-shut-down-what-passengers-need-to-know.html
content_expanded:
With Brussels Airport closed through at least Thursday, most airlines responded by putting into effect change and refund policies for passengers with tickets arriving at or departing from Belgium’s capital.

Regardless of airline policies, travel insurance may protect Brussels-bound travelers, said Stan Sandberg, a founder of the insurance comparison site TravelInsurance.com.

Many travel insurance plans offer trip cancellation coverage for terrorist attacks that are recognized as such by the State Department in Washington, provided the coverage is bought before the assault, he said. The typical cancellation coverage will apply to travelers who are scheduled to travel within seven to 30 days of the attack.

With Brussels Airport Shut Down, What Travelers Need to Know

By SHIVANI VORA

Following the terrorist attacks in Belgium, many airlines are offering refunds or allowing passengers to postpone flights to or from Brussels.

title: Highlights of Prosecutor’s News Conference
content: Highlights from the news conference by the Belgian federal prosecutor, Frédéric Van Leeuw, on Wednesday, at which he said the new toll from the attacks was 31 dead and 270 wounded. Airport · The first explosion, at Row 11 of the departure hall, took place at 7:58 a.m. · A second explosion occurred nine seconds later, in Row 2. · One of the suicide bombings at the airport was carried out by Ibrahim el-Bakraoui, who was identified by his fingerprints. He was the middle person in a widely circulated image of three suspects taken from surveillance video at the airport. · A bag carried by the suspect who wore white in the surveillance video contained large amounts of explosives. That device was not detonated and was later handled by a bomb-disposal crew. · Acting on a tip from a taxi driver, the police raided a house on 4, rue Max Roos, in the Schaerbeek neighborhood of Brussels. · The police found 15 kilograms, or 33 pounds, of the explosive material TATP; 150 liters, or 40 gallons, of acetone; 30 liters of hydrogen peroxide; detonators, a suitcase full of nails and screws; and other material, including plastic bins and fans. · In a trash can on that same street, police officers found a computer with Ibrahim el-Bakraoui's will on it. Maelbeek Station · The subway train was leaving Maelbeek station for Arts-Loi station when a bomb went off in the second car. · The suicide bomber at the station has been identified as Khalid el-Bakraoui, who was also identified by fingerprints. · Khalid el-Bakraoui and his brother Ibrahim had criminal records but no established links to terrorism.
content_expanded:
Highlights from the news conference by the Belgian federal prosecutor, Frédéric Van Leeuw, on Wednesday, at which he said the new toll from the attacks was 31 dead and 270 wounded.

Airport

· The first explosion, at Row 11 of the departure hall, took place at 7:58 a.m.
· A second explosion occurred nine seconds later, in Row 2.
· One of the suicide bombings at the airport was carried out by Ibrahim el-Bakraoui, who was identified by his fingerprints. He was the middle person in a widely circulated image of three suspects taken from surveillance video at the airport.
· A bag carried by the suspect who wore white in the surveillance video contained large amounts of explosives. That device was not detonated and was later handled by a bomb-disposal crew.
· Acting on a tip from a taxi driver, the police raided a house on 4, rue Max Roos, in the Schaerbeek neighborhood of Brussels.
· The police found 15 kilograms, or 33 pounds, of the explosive material TATP; 150 liters, or 40 gallons, of acetone; 30 liters of hydrogen peroxide; detonators, a suitcase full of nails and screws; and other material, including plastic bins and fans.
· In a trash can on that same street, police officers found a computer with Ibrahim el-Bakraoui’s will on it.

Maelbeek Station

· The subway train was leaving Maelbeek station for Arts-Loi station when a bomb went off in the second car.
· The suicide bomber at the station has been identified as Khalid el-Bakraoui, who was also identified by fingerprints.
· Khalid el-Bakraoui and his brother Ibrahim had criminal records but no established links to terrorism.

title: Interpol Was Seeking Khalid el-Bakraoui Before the Attacks
content: [nytmedia id="100000004288144" crop="190" type="image"] Khalid el-Bakraoui, one of the brothers who are suspected of bombing the airport and a subway station in Brussels on Tuesday, was the subject of an Interpol “red notice,” an alert to police forces around the world saying that he was wanted in Belgium on terrorism charges. Excerpts from the notice that were posted publicly by Interpol say he was born on Jan. 12, 1989, that he spoke French and Arabic, and that he had dual Belgian and Bahamian nationality. He has been wanted since last August. There does not appear to be a red notice posted on the Interpol website for his brother, Ibrahim.
content_expanded:
Khalid el-Bakraoui, one of the brothers who are suspected of bombing the airport and a subway station in Brussels on Tuesday, was the subject of an Interpol “red notice,” an alert to police forces around the world saying that he was wanted in Belgium on terrorism charges.

Excerpts from the notice that were posted publicly by Interpol say he was born on Jan. 12, 1989, that he spoke French and Arabic, and that he had dual Belgian and Bahamian nationality. He has been wanted since last August.

There does not appear to be a red notice posted on the Interpol website for his brother, Ibrahim.
